column1: The Timucua and the Calusa were the earliest known inhabitants of the land that would become Winter Haven. Both of these groups were deeply impacted by war and disease from the Spanish conquest of Florida in the early 1500s. The Timucua were particularly affected by the expedition of Hernando de Soto. By the 19th century
column2: both these groups no longer existed. During these expeditions the Spanish explorers claimed the entire peninsula of Florida for the Spanish monarchy

column2: Chipco
column3: and his followers were known to live in the Winter Haven area. Several small skirmishes during the war were fought in and around Winter Haven.

column6: including mapping many of the local lakes. The first maps of the area were published by the United States government in 1854. In 1883

column1: Pughsville was a neighborhood of Winter Haven where African Americans built a community after the Civil War. A historical marker on Highway 17 at Avenue O commemorates the community. According to the marker
column2: Pughsville was one of Winter Haven's earliest neighborhoods and was settled by African Americans who cleared the land in the southwest section of the city.

column1: Pughsville was named for an early black pioneer
column2: Reverend Charles Pugh
column3: who was a founder of one of Zion Hill Missionary Baptist Church. Pughsville was also home to Bethel A.M.E.
column5: and Church of Christ. The community was most active from the 1900s until the 1950s and had an African-American school
column8: and restaurants where some residents worked. Others worked in the citrus industry or in state or federal jobs. Pughsville produced Winter Haven's first African-American commissioner and mayor Lemuel Geathers
column10: fire fighter and postal worker. The community declined in the late 1970s as larger commercial establishments began arriving in the area.

column1: According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 25.4 square miles (66 km2)
column3: of which 17.7 square miles (46 km2) is land and 7.7 square miles (20 km2) (30.45%) is water. Winter Haven is located within the Central Florida Highlands area of the Atlantic coastal plain with a terrain consisting of flatland interspersed with gently rolling hills. It has an average elevation of 146 feet (45 m) above sea-level. The city is located at the headwaters of the Peace River.

column1: Winter Haven has 50 lakes within its borders
column2: including its famous Chain of Lakes. The lakes are by far the city's most distinctive feature. Winter Haven bills itself as "The Chain of Lakes City". The city has two prominent chains of lakes; the northern chain has nine lakes interconnected by a series of canals. The southern chain features sixteen lakes interconnected by a series of canals. The southern chain has several prominent lakes
column3: including Lake Eloise
column5: and Lake Lulu. In 2011
column6: after six years of construction and political infighting
column7: Winter Haven opened a canal lock system connecting the two chains. Most of the lakes in Winter Haven formed in a similar fashion to sinkholes
column8: through dissolving of the limestone ground. These types of lakes are called "solution lakes". The lakes in Winter Haven teem with life
column12: and more. The Winter Haven lakes are a world-renowned spot for bass fishing.

column1: Winter Haven is located in the humid subtropical zone (Köppen climate classification: Cfa). The city gets its name from its comparative lack of colder weather. The average temperature is 73.2 °F (23 °C). The city averages 50.3 inches (128 cm) of rain per year. The summer months of June
column2: July
column3: August
column5: which includes the height of the Atlantic hurricane season
column6: are by far the rainiest time of the year. Those four months
column7: which average 29.7 inches (75 cm) of rain per year
column8: account for more than half of the annual rainfall. Winters in Winter Haven are dry and sunny
column9: with mild temperatures with highs of 73–77 °F (23–25 °C) and lows of 50–53 °F (10–12 °C). Frosts occur on one or two nights per year on average.
